awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Enabling high-throughput data management in scientific domains
awd_abstract_narration:
Many scientific domains have entered a data-driven era, in which scientific discovery depends heavily on effective and efficient analysis of large-scale data generated by wet-bench experiments or computer simulations. Current database management systems (DBMSs), while being very popular in the business world, fall short in high-throughput data processing required by scientific applications. The goal of this project is to design and implement a novel data management software architecture that enables high-throughput data management services for general scientific communities. The project achieves this goal via (1) a novel one-scan-fits-all data processing framework based on repetitive scans of large data sources; (2) a query engine that leverages the massive computing power of modern Graphics Processing Units (GPU) hardware; and (3) design and implementation of algorithms for popular analytics in three scientific domains on top of the query engine to demonstrate the effectiveness and efficiency of the proposed architecture.  The project also aims at building a software prototype and evaluating this prototype with real-world scientific datasets and query workloads. 

The project is expected to provide a highly efficient solution to satisfy the data management needs of a wide range of scientific fields. To deliver comparable performance, the proposed architecture requires only a fraction of the hardware and energy costs needed by existing systems. As a result, it has the potential to make scientific studies that are regarded as difficult or infeasible a reality. Integration of proposed research into educational endeavors that contribute to broadening the influence of computer science, nurturing the next generation of multidisciplinary scientists, and boosting the success of minority and women students in the computer science and engineering field are other broader impact activities planned.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
With the development of advanced instrumentation and computer simulations, many scientific fields have entered a data-driven era. The storage, querying, and analysis of scientific data, however, impose great challenges to database management systems (DBMS)technology due to the large data volume and complex analytical query workload. This project attempts to meet such challenges via design and implementation of a novel system that enables high-throughput data management services for the scientific communities.

During the project period, we have identified and tackled challenges in building such a scientific database system. The key thoughts can be summarized in two aspects. (1) our system utilizes the most efficient parallel computing hardware in today's market, namely, the GPUs, as the platform for in-core data processing. With a complex hardware architecture that is totally different from that of the CPUs, GPU database system is a largely unexplored field. We have accomplished innovative research on key aspects of database systems such as join algorithms, user-defined functions, multi-query optimization, resource allocation and data indexing on GPUs. (2) we design our system following the idea of minimizing redundant computation among user tasks. In existing DBMSs, such tasks (i.e., queries) are processed largely in an independent way yet people have identified significant amount of common components that can be shared among tasks. To maximize such sharing, we propose a novel relational algebraic framework for combining concurrent queries into a global computation. As a result, we effectively removed the I/O bottleneck that is common in database workloads, which furthermore improved the utilization of GPU resources. 

As a result of above innovations, our system provides performance advantages of at least one order of magnitude over the best existing solutions, as shown by extensive experiments run on a prototype of our system.

The intellectual achievements of this project are mainly seen from the design, implementation, and optimization of the proposed database engine. Our work complements established research in both DBMS and general-purpose GPU (GPGPU) computing. On the DBMS side, we have extended the theory and practice of relational query processing and optimization. While existing GPGPU work focused on accelerating individual computation-intensive tasks, we pioneered in developing a system software on general-purpose data retrieval and analysis on GPUs.   Research results from this project have been reported in 20 peer-reviewed articles, two PhD dissertations, and one MS thesis. Four US patent applications with claims originated from work done in this project are under review. 

The broader impacts of this project are first demonstrated by the high-performance data analysis capabilities brought by our system to various scientific domains such as biophysics and bioinformatics. However, by presenting an extremely efficient SQL query processing engine, we extend impacts to many business domains such as finance, smart city, and online advertising. In fact, the project team gained much confidence in the economical/societal value of the technologies developed out of this project via a follow-up NSF I-Corps training project, and is actively involved in the commercialization of such technologies. 

The integrated research and educational plans made significant contributions to broadening the influence of computer science, nurturing the next generation of multidisciplinary scientists, and boosting the participation of minority and women students in the computer science and engineering field. The project provided educational opportunities in the context of GPU computing for 190+ graduate and undergraduate students. The project enabled rigorous training in DBMS design and implementation and GPGPU for 7 PhD students in the CS field. It also enhanced the training of 3 PhD students specializing in computational physics by their exposure to the fundamentals and tools of computer science. Over one-third of aforementioned students are from a group underrepresented in the CSE field. 

 


Last Modified: 08/29/2019
Modified by: Yicheng Tu
